items.title: Blue Origin Lands Booster After Rocket Launch and Matches SpaceX’s Feat
items.summary: The lower half of the New Glenn rocket set down on a platform in the Atlantic Ocean after lifting a small NASA Mars mission to space.

items.title: The Dogs of 8,000 B.C. Were Amazingly Diverse
items.summary: The staggering array of modern dog breeds is typically traced to the Victorian era. But half of all canine variation was in place roughly 10,000 years ago, a new study suggests.

items.title: Bird Flu Ravaged the World’s Largest Elephant Seal Population, Study Finds
items.summary: After the H5N1 virus hit the remote island of South Georgia in 2023, more than 50,000 breeding females may have disappeared.

items.title: Northern Lights Are Beautiful, but for Satellites They’re Risky
items.summary: At least one space launch has been put on hold, as satellite operators and rocket companies manage the effects of the current geomagnetic storm hitting Earth.

items.title: How to See the Northern Lights on Wednesday
items.summary: A geomagnetic storm made the aurora borealis visible across a swath of the United States again on Wednesday, illuminating the skies as far south as Arizona.

items.title: At the Cybathlon, May the Best Brain-Computer Interface Win
items.summary: Every four years at the Cybathlon, teams of researchers and technology “pilots” compete to see whose brain-computer interface holds the most promise.

items.title: The ‘Lost Sisters’ of the Pleiades Fill the Entire Night Sky
items.summary: Astronomers identified more than 3,000 stars associated with the cluster, and there might be even more.

items.title: Everyone’s Asking How Comet 3I/ATLAS Got to Our Solar System
items.summary: Scientists who study comets are struggling to keep up with popular speculation that the interstellar object 3I/ATLAS was sent to our solar system by an alien intelligence.

items.title: Infant Formula Company Tied to Botulism Outbreak Had Known Problems
items.summary: A Pennsylvania plant run by the company, ByHeart, was shut down this year after inspectors found mold, a leaking roof and more than 2,500 dead insects in a food production area.

items.title: The Global Climate Leadership Vacuum
items.summary: The United States is largely absent from the United Nations climate negations in Brazil. So who is stepping up?

items.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Head for a Record in 2025, Global Carbon Project Reports
items.summary: But there are signs that greenhouse gas pollution in China might be slowing, according to a new analysis.

items.title: Visiting Leiden, Canals and Charm Without the Crowds of Amsterdam
items.summary: Leiden, a city whose university is often called the Oxford of the Netherlands, features museums, gardens, murals and plenty of ways to stretch your mind.

items.title: Scientists Grow More Hopeful About Ending a Global Organ Shortage
items.summary: At an international conference, researchers at the forefront of animal-human transplantation compared notes and allowed themselves the first real optimism in decades.

items.title: Northern Lights Bring Dazzling Views to Northeast U.S. and Across Canada, With More Possible Tonight
items.summary: After a colorful display overnight, the northern U.S., parts of Canada and Britain could see the aurora Wednesday night.

items.title: There’s a New Forecast for Peak Oil Demand. It’s Increasingly Cloudy.
items.summary: The International Energy Agency once projected that oil and gas demand could level off by 2030. Now it’s backing off, sort of.

items.title: Newsom in the Spotlight at the Climate Conference That Trump Decided to Skip
items.summary: The California governor painted the president as a threat to American competitiveness by letting China dominate the renewable energy industry.

items.title: F.D.A. Names Agency Veteran to Run Drug Division
items.summary: Dr. Richard Pazdur, who has been the F.D.A.’s top cancer drug regulator, represents a stabilizing choice for an agency reeling under staff cuts and low morale.

items.title: Nolan Williams, Who Stimulated the Brain to Treat Depression, Dies at 43
items.summary: A neuroscientist, he employed a battery of high-tech tools in devising a fast-acting therapy that targets the area of the brain where depression originates.

items.title: Trump Is Said to Propose Opening California Coast to Oil Drilling
items.summary: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a chief critic of the president and an opponent of oil exploration in the Pacific, called the proposal “dead on arrival.”

items.title: How a Sea Creature’s Fossils Show All the Colors of the Rainbow
items.summary: The brilliant iridescent hues found in ammolite come from tiny air gaps in the fossils’ layers, a new study finds.

items.title: For Parents of Children With Autism, There Are No Easy Answers
items.summary: Two reporters wanted to witness firsthand how doctors and families navigate mixed messages and unproven claims.

items.title: The Young Women Grappling With an ‘Old Man’s Disease’
items.summary: Diagnosed with A.L.S., they traded stories, drank tequila and made grim jokes at a unique annual gathering on Cape Cod.

items.title: At COP30 in Belém, Brazil, Chinese Technology Is Shifting Climate Politics
items.summary: At this year’s climate summit, the United States is out and Europe is struggling. But emerging countries are embracing renewable energy thanks to a glut of cheap equipment.

items.title: Why Everyone Wants to Meet the ‘World’s Most Boring Man’
items.summary: Politicians, oil giants and climate activists hang on his every word. The Trump administration has blasted him. How did Fatih Birol get so big?

items.title: Blue Origin Scrubs Launch of NASA’s ESCAPADE Mission to Mars
items.summary: The second flight of the orbital rocket from Jeff Bezos’s space company was halted by weather. The company may try again on Wednesday.

items.title: Merck PCSK9 Pill Results Point to Extremely Low Cholesterol Future
items.summary: The drug targets the PCSK9 protein, and could give millions of people a more affordable option to reduce their heart disease risk.

items.title: Robert H. Bartlett, Father of Innovative Life-Support System, Dies at 86
items.summary: He developed extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, a treatment that can sustain patients whose hearts and lungs are failing — for days or weeks or longer.

items.title: Stinking, Spongy, Dark, Huge: A Spider Web Unlike Any Seen Before
items.summary: A pitch-black cave in the Balkans is home to what researchers say is a singular work of cooperation by two usually-hostile species of spider.

items.title: After Hurricane Melissa, Solar Power Kept the Electricity on for Some Jamaicans
items.summary: People with rooftop solar panels got their power back almost immediately. The ‘entire neighborhood benefits,’ one resident said.

items.title: The DNA Helix Changed How We Thought About Ourselves
items.summary: “The laws of inheritance are quite unknown,” Charles Darwin acknowledged in 1859. The discovery of DNA’s shape altered how we conceived of life itself.

items.title: James D. Watson, Co-Discoverer of the Structure of DNA, Is Dead at 97
items.summary: His decoding of the blueprint for life with Francis H.C. Crick made him one of the most important scientists of the 20th century. He wrote a celebrated memoir and later ignited an uproar with racist views.

items.title: Leaders at COP30 Climate Summit in Belém Focus on the Rising Toll of Warming
items.summary: “All we have to do is look outside,” one delegate said. “The sea rises, the coral dies.”
